item.title: Labour accuses Boris Johnson of lying over flat renovation costs
item.description: Jonathan Ashworth calls for a "full and frank explanation" of who paid for works in Downing Street.

item.title: Arlene Foster: Letter of no confidence sent to DUP politicians
item.description: Party MPs, NI Assembly members and councillors have signed a letter challenging leader Arlene Foster.

item.title: Tate Modern attack: Jonty Bravery had history of violence, report finds
item.description: Jonty Bravery threw a six-year-old boy from a 10th floor viewing platform at London's Tate Modern.

item.title: India Covid: Delhi builds makeshift funeral pyres as deaths climb
item.description: India's capital struggles to find space to cremate its dead during the second wave of the pandemic.

item.title: Queen pictured resuming public duties after duke's death
item.description: The monarch is seen carrying out virtual audiences for the first time since Prince Philip's death.

item.title: Covid-19: Vaccine offered to 42-year-olds and Delhi deaths climb
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday evening.

item.title: Covid-19: Vaccine offered to 42-year-olds in England
item.description: Those who are due to turn 42 by 1 July can also book their jabs on the NHS website.

item.title: Brexit: Tensions overshadow EU vote on UK trade deal
item.description: Euro MPs are set to back the EU-UK trade deal despite rows over fishing and Northern Ireland.

item.title: High Court to look at PM's Patel 'bullying' decision
item.description: Boris Johnson kept the home secretary in post, saying she had not broken Whitehall's rules.

item.title: Autistic teens face 'barbaric' treatment, parents tell MPs
item.description: Parents tell MPs their children were restrained unnecessarily and isolated from their families.

item.title: UK weather: April set to be frostiest in UK for 60 years
item.description: This month saw 13 days of air frosts in the UK, compared with the previous record of 11 in April 1970.

item.title: City of London to convert offices into homes in post-Covid revamp
item.description: The City of London Corporation set out plans on Tuesday to create 1,500 new residential units by 2030.

item.title: Crocs sales soar in fashion comeback
item.description: The divisive footwear company's sales reached a record $460m in its first quarter.

item.title: Pink Supermoon seen around the world
item.description: Stargazers were treated to the fourth full Moon of 2021 on Monday night.

item.title: Youngest Mastermind winner: 'It feels like a dream'
item.description: Jonathan Gibson won the competition by four points and got a perfect score in his specialist subject.

item.title: NHS heroes to feature in Royal Society of Portrait Painters exhibition
item.description: Images of medical staff on the frontline of the Covid-19 battle will be a highlight of the show.

item.title: Glasgow student is youngest Mastermind champion at 24
item.description: Jonathan Gibson from Glasgow won the final of the long-running BBC quiz show by four points.

item.title: Covid-19 in India: Cases, deaths and oxygen supply
item.description: Maps, charts and graphics explaining what is happening and what the authorities are doing about it.

item.title: UK's first hijabi firefighter: ‘Firefighters don’t look like me’
item.description: Uroosa Arshid says she hopes other young Muslim women may feel inspired to follow in her footsteps.

item.title: Recovering from lockdown: Five tips to boost your child's vocabulary
item.description: Research shows the lockdown has had an impact on young children's language skills. How can parents help?

item.title: Book sales surge in 2020 as UK rediscovers love of reading
item.description: Sales of fiction, non-fiction and audio books all jumped last year, the industry body says.

item.title: Kanye West's Yeezy trainers sell for record $1.8m
item.description: The musician's prototype trainers are the first to fetch more than $1m at auction.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards: Diversity's BGT routine up for must-see moment award
item.description: The controversial routine is among the nominees for Bafta's must-see TV moment of the last year.

item.title: Belfast girl goes from Park Runs to being world's fastest at 12
item.description: Belfast girl Emer McKee says she just tries to "run as fast as I can" after setting a new world 5km record for a 12-year-old.

item.title: Firefighter who became defining image of mountain gorse fire
item.description: A photo of firefighter Hayley Agnew became the defining image of the Slieve Donard gorse fire.

item.title: Nigeria: The community that trades by barter instead of money
item.description: This Nigerian community still practices trade by barter, where goods are exchanged instead of money.

item.title: India Covid: The messages deciding between life and death
item.description: Avani Singh was one of thousands of Indians who turned to social media to get help for her family.

item.title: Downing Street flat: What are the rules about political donations?
item.description: Boris Johnson is under mounting pressure over the funding of his Downing Street flat renovations.

item.title: CC Clarke: The mum-shaming on social media is mind-blowing
item.description: Beauty influencer CC Clarke on dealing with "mum-shaming" from trolls on her social media accounts.

item.title: Afghan interpreters rejected for resettlement fear death after UK exit
item.description: Campaigners say many interpreters fired for trivial reasons are being unfairly barred from the UK.

item.title: Scottish Election 2021: Have the parties lost their momentum?
item.description: Prof Sir John Curtice looks at where the parties stand in polling ahead of the Scottish Parliament election.

item.title: Vegan butchers: Could one be opening on your high street?
item.description: Is the arrival of vegan butchers on high streets the logical next step in the fake meat trend?

item.title: Electric cars: What will happen to all the dead batteries?
item.description: In the next 10 years millions of old electric car batteries will need to be recycled or discarded.

item.title: Inside a long Covid clinic: 'I want to play with my kids again'
item.description: Croydon University Hospital's clinic has already seen 1,000 patients, with another 500 on the waiting list.

item.title: Sir Tom Jones: 'I might be old but my voice is still young'
item.description: The star on his lost McCartney collaboration, fighting US censors and why he's not a covers artist.

item.title: France-Algeria relations: The lingering fallout from nuclear tests in the Sahara
item.description: France says the tests were carried out in uninhabited areas but local residents beg to differ.

item.title: Five questions for the PM and why the answers matter
item.description: Boris Johnson is under scrutiny over allegations which concern standards in public life.

item.title: Oscars 2021: Audiences turn away as a sluggish ceremony leaves critics cold
item.description: Fewer than 10 million people watched the 2021 Oscars, which critics described as a "trainwreck".

item.title: Arsenal owners remain '100% committed' to club and are 'not selling any stake'
item.description: Arsenal owners Stan Kroenke and Josh Kroenke say they remain "100% committed" to the Premier League club and "are not selling any stake".

item.title: Wimbledon to scrap middle Sunday from 2022 and hopes for at least 25% fans in 2021
item.description: Wimbledon will abandon its traditional rest day on the middle Sunday of the tournament from 2022.

item.title: Teams to be allowed 26-man Euro 2020 squads
item.description: Teams will be allowed to select a 26-player squad instead of the usual 23 at this summer's European Championship.

item.title: 'A pairing made to destroy rivals' hope' - why Nagelsmann and Bayern are the perfect fit
item.description: Bayern Munich's move for RB Leipzig coach Julian Nagelsmann is one designed to show dominance and destroy hope, writes Constantin Eckner.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs, cafes and restaurants are now allowed to reopen indoors and outdoors in Scotland - and outdoors in Wales.

item.title: Covid: When, where and how can I go on holiday?
item.description: The rules on where you can holiday in the UK are being relaxed - but there are still many things can't do.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 42 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules have been eased further across the UK - more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Lateral-flow tests: What are the risks and benefits?
item.description: What are the risks and benefits from using wide-scale lateral-flow tests?

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: India Covid: Patients dying without oxygen amid Delhi surge
item.description: Delhi hospitals run out of beds and oxygen as families struggle to save their loved ones.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel through two south London boroughs are being urged to take a Covid-19 test.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: India has now been added to the UK Government's Covid "red list" of countries.

item.title: India Covid crisis: Did election rallies help spread virus?
item.description: Did campaigning for state elections in India help coronavirus to spread?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: A nightmare on repeat - India is running out of oxygen again
item.description: Facing a rising wave of coronavirus, and record case numbers, India finds itself battling for breath.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Pubs, cafes and restaurants are reopening in Wales and Scotland - as part of significant easing of lockdown rules.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 33 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the UK's plans?
item.description: The government is considering how people could prove they are unlikely to transmit Covid.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Is the Australia-NZ travel bubble the way ahead?
item.description: Australia and New Zealand have quarantine-free travel, but will other countries follow their lead?

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: How the Bay of Pigs invasion began - and failed - 60 years on
item.description: The story of the attempted overthrow of Castro's regime in Cuba, as told by the men who were there.

item.title: Afghanistan War: How can the West fight terrorism after leaving?
item.description: As Western troops prepare to go, there are concerns over the future of counter-terrorism operations.

item.title: Big Dog's Backyard Ultra: The toughest, weirdest race you've never heard of
item.description: The format might be simple - winning this race is anything but. Big Dog's Backyard Ultra is an unusually punishing challenge.

item.title: 'My sister took her life, petrified at facing her ex in court'
item.description: Gemma Robinson died just days before she was due to see her ex-partner in court.

item.title: The disabled doctors not believed by their colleagues
item.description: People often feel nervous when they visit a doctor, but what if you are a doctor but your colleagues don't believe you're ill?

item.title: The homeless drug addict who became a professor
item.description: Jesse Thistle, a high school dropout, overcame addiction and homelessness to pursue an academic career.
